headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; The Kansas Question in Congress--Doubts of the President as to the Result--Minister to Prussia--The Case of Mr. Matteson, &c. FROM WASHINGTON. By Telegraph to the New-York Times. Magnetic Telegraph Co.'s Ofices-No. 46 Wall-st., and 181 Broadway.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the time for action on Kansas affairs approaches, the President begins to be seriously doubtful of the result in Congress. The defection of the Pennsylvania delegation is very threatening; ditto New-York, six of whom are far from having decided to vote Lecompton through. The Ohio delegation is a unit against it, and very little reliance,

headline.main: VERY LATE FROM UTAH.; IMMENSE CROPS IN UTAH. Mormon Account of Grievances. LATEST FROM THE ARMY. ECHO CANON FORTIFIED. MORMON PREPARATIONS A Guerilla Warfare Determined Upon.

docs.lead_paragraph: We have had an interview with gentleman who has just arrived in this City from California and Salt Lake City direct having left the Mormon head-quarters on the 10th of December--a date fully one month later than previous advices. headline.main: The Case of T. W. Smith.

docs.lead_paragraph: The application of Miss SMITH for the possession of her brother, THOMAS WASHINGTON SMITH, recently cleared of the charge of murdering RICHARD CARTER, the President of the Tamaqua Bank, on the ground of insanity, was argued before the Court this morning.

headline.main: THE BANK OF PENNSYLVANIA.; Letter from Mr. Thomas Allibone.

docs.lead_paragraph: TO THE PUBLIC. A most cruel and unjust assault having been made me in an affidavid, in which it has been sworn that " I had absconded with intent to defraud my creditors"-and every possible publicity having been given to this outrage, is my apology for calling the attention of the public to the following facts, which I submit to my fallow-citizens on this, the day succeeding my arrival at home:

headline.main: Senator Hale on the Dred Scott Decision-Inspection of Seagoing Vessels-Secretary Cass' Second Reception, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: The rural districts of Massachusetts send practical men to the Legislature. A Boston paper tells the following: "One of our merchants while sitting in his counting-room, cogitating upon the hard times, had his reveries disturbed by the entrance of a gentle-man. 'Do you want any last-rate brooms? `No,' he replied, 'we have a full supply.' 'I've got some very cheap,' was the rejoinder. 'I made 'em myself, and I'm a member of the Legislater.' "

docs.lead_paragraph: Returns of the Kansas election, received in St. Louis, as published over the signature of Gov. DENVAR and the presiding officers of the Territo. rial Legislature, show that the Free-State men elected their entire State ticket by an average majority of 415. The majority against the Constitution, counting in the alleged frauds in Oxford, Shawnee, Kickapoo, and other places, is 1,226.
